In the "functor of points" approach one sees a scheme as a functor

X:CRing⟶Set.X:\mathbf{CRing}\longrightarrow\mathbf{Set}.X:CRing⟶Set.

In the introduction to the second edition of EGA I, Grothendieck shows how, in the affine case, one may recover the points of the underlying scheme. The idea is that the points of XXX should morally be given by

⋃k fieldX(k)\bigcup_{k\text{ field}} X(k)⋃k field​X(k)

(see also this Mathoverflow question). However, the above is a proper class, so one considers the following equivalence relation: given f∈X(k)f\in X(k)f∈X(k) and f′∈X(k′)f'\in X(k')f′∈X(k′), we set f∼f′f\sim f'f∼f′ iff there exists a common field extension i:k→Ki:k\to Ki:k→K, i′:k′→Ki':k'\to Ki′:k′→K such that X(i)(f)=X(i′)(f′)X(i)(f)=X(i')(f')X(i)(f)=X(i′)(f′). The intuition is that X(k)X(k)X(k) is the set of solutions of some kind of system of polynomial equations in the field kkk, and we shouldn't distinguish, say, the solution 333 as a rational number from the solution 333 as a real or complex number (but we should distinguish it from the solution we would usually denote by 333 in the field F7\mathbb F_7F7​, for example).

Now, if X=CRing(R,−)X=\mathbf{CRing}(R,-)X=CRing(R,−), i.e., if it is the functor of points of SpecR\mathrm{Spec} RSpecR for some commutative ring RRR, then f∈X(k)f\in X(k)f∈X(k) means that fff is a homomorphism R→kR\to kR→k, and it turns out that

Lemma. f∼f′f\sim f'f∼f′ iff ker⁡f=ker⁡f′.\ker f=\ker f'.kerf=kerf′.

It is immediate to check that ker⁡f\ker fkerf is a prime ideal of RRR because the target is a field. It is a bit less immediate (at least for me) but it is also true that any prime ideal of RRR is of the form ker⁡f\ker fkerf for some f:R→kf:R\to kf:R→k with target a field. So we get exactly the points of the underlying topological space of XXX qua locally ringed space. Cool!

My problem, in all this, is that I can't prove the lemma. The left-to-right direction is immediate. The converse escapes my (very limited) commutative algebra skills. Here is how I tried to go about it.

We have a commutative ring RRR and two homomorphisms f:R→kf:R\to kf:R→k, f′:R→k′f':R\to k'f′:R→k′ with k,k′k,k'k,k′ fields such that ker⁡f=ker⁡f′\ker f=\ker f'kerf=kerf′. We need to find a field KKK which is a common extension of kkk and k′k'k′ and which makes fff and f′f'f′ equal by postcomposition. An obvious possibility is to compute the pushout k⊗Rk′k\otimes_R k'k⊗R​k′ in CRing\mathbf{CRing}CRing, which is a commutative ring, then we take an arbitrary maximal ideal m\mathfrak mm in it, and k⊗Rk′/mk\otimes_R k'/\mathfrak mk⊗R​k′/m is the field we're looking for.

There's problem though: we never used the assumption ker⁡f=ker⁡f′\ker f=\ker f'kerf=kerf′! But there's a catch: by taking a maximal ideal, we implicitly supposed k⊗Rk′k\otimes_R k'k⊗R​k′ to be non-zero. So, I would like to prove that ker⁡f=ker⁡f′\ker f=\ker f'kerf=kerf′ implies k⊗Rk′≠0k\otimes_R k'\neq 0k⊗R​k′=0, but this is where I get stuck. Does anyone know how to do this?
Another, "bonus" question: does the above recipe for reconstructing the points of the underlying topological space work for any scheme XXX, or just for the affine ones?

This may be killing a gnat with a bazooka, but one idea is that first of all R/p⊗RR/p≅R/p⊗R/pR/p≅R/pR/\mathfrak{p} \otimes_R R/\mathfrak{p} \cong R/\mathfrak{p} \otimes_{R/\mathfrak{p}} R/\mathfrak{p} \cong R/\mathfrak{p}R/p⊗R​R/p≅R/p⊗R/p​R/p≅R/p, and also that the field of fractions KKK of R/pR/\mathfrak{p}R/p is a flat module over R/pR/\mathfrak{p}R/p (because it is a filtered colimit of free modules 1xR/p\frac{1}{x} R/\mathfrak{p}x1​R/p where xxx ranges over nonzero elements. So when you apply K⊗R/p−K \otimes_{R/\mathfrak{p}} -K⊗R/p​− to the inclusion R/p↪K′R/\mathfrak{p} \hookrightarrow K'R/p↪K′, you again get a monomorphism (exploiting flatness).

(This may be harder than necessary, but I think something along these lines will work.)

I obviously need to up my commutative algebra game since I wouldn't have been able to think of Todd's argument, nor do I see a more elementary proof. I feel there should be something more elementary.

Damiano Mazza said:

Another, "bonus" question: does the above recipe for reconstructing the points of the underlying topological space work for any scheme XXX, or just for the affine ones?

Lemma 26.13.3. of the Stacks Project may help here:

Let X be a scheme. Points of X correspond bijectively to equivalence classes of morphisms from spectra of fields into X.

and also the surrounding material.

It looks to me like it's the right-to-left direction that you're trying to prove. The way I would think of approaching it is to take the quotient R/KR/KR/K where K=ker⁡f=ker⁡f′K=\ker f = \ker f'K=kerf=kerf′. Since KKK Is a prime ideal, R/KR/KR/K is an integral domain that maps injectively to kkk and k′k'k′; thus its field of fractions ought also to inject into both of them. Now I feel like that should mean that kkk and k′k'k′ should have a "union" over this field of fractions, but my field theory isn't strong enough to be positive.
Hmm, possibly the existence of such unions is already implicit in the transitivity of ∼\sim∼.
Oh yes, Mike's right, my suggestion didn't say anything about a common field extension. I was really just focused on proving Damiano's conjecture that k⊗Rk′≠0k \otimes_R k' \neq 0k⊗R​k′=0.

I feel that this business of trying to find the smallest field that contains kkk and k′k'k′ is connected to what people call the "composite" or "compositum" of fields:

  • Wikipedia, Composite of fields.
but in the study of "composites" they tend to assume kkk and k′k'k′ are both subfields of some larger field, e.g. an algebraic closure of FFF if both kkk and k′k'k′ are algebraic extensions of FFF.
I suspect that this larger subfield is a kind of crutch.

Oh, I see. So assuming k⊗Rk′≠0k \otimes_R k' \neq 0k⊗R​k′=0 (which is what I had focused on), which is the coproduct of k,k′k, k'k,k′ in the category of commutative RRR-algebras, take a maximal ideal in this commutative ring, say m\mathfrak{m}m. Then
(k⊗Rk′)/m(k \otimes_R k')/\mathfrak{m}(k⊗R​k′)/m is a field. But then we have a composition of maps

k→k⊗Rk′→(k⊗Rk′)/mk \to k \otimes_R k' \to (k \otimes_R k')/\mathfrak{m}k→k⊗R​k′→(k⊗R​k′)/m

where the first map is a coproduct coprojection. Since this is a map between fields, it is injective. So kkk, and k′k'k′ by the same argument, both inject into a common field, and we are done.

Thanks to everyone for your answers/suggestions! @Mike Shulman, I did swap left and right, sorry! :blush: (I edited it now). I think that your idea is related to @Todd Trimble's argument. Mixing the two, here is a possible proof.

Like I said in my original post (and as observed by Todd in his last comment), given f:R→kf:R\to kf:R→k and f′:R→k′f':R\to k'f′:R→k′ with k,k′k,k'k,k′ fields, to prove that ker⁡f=ker⁡f′\ker f=\ker f'kerf=kerf′ implies f∼f′f\sim f'f∼f′ it is enough to find a non-zero ring SSS and (necessarily injective) homomorphisms g:k→Sg:k\to Sg:k→S and g′:k′→Sg':k'\to Sg′:k′→S such that gf=g′f′gf=g'f'gf=g′f′, because then any S/mS/\mathfrak mS/m, where m\mathfrak mm is a maximal ideal of SSS, is a field with the property we're looking for. My idea was to take S:=k⊗Rk′S:=k\otimes_R k'S:=k⊗R​k′, and Todd's argument (if I understand it correctly) shows that it works, but there's a simpler argument, not invoking flatness.

We start by letting p:=ker⁡f=ker⁡f′\mathfrak p:=\ker f=\ker f'p:=kerf=kerf′, which is a prime ideal of RRR. As both Todd and Mike suggested, both fff and f′f'f′ factor through R/pR/\mathfrak pR/p, which is an integral domain, via monos mmm and m′m'm′ into kkk and k′k'k′, respectively. Let K:=Frac(R/p)K:=\mathrm{Frac}(R/\mathfrak p)K:=Frac(R/p) be the field of fractions of R/pR/\mathfrak pR/p. By its universal property, we have that mmm and m′m'm′ factor through KKK via monos K→kK\to kK→k and K→k′K\to k'K→k′.

Now, these exhibit kkk and k′k'k′ as KKK-algebras. In particular, they are non-zero KKK-vector spaces, and their tensor product S:=k⊗Kk′S:=k\otimes_K k'S:=k⊗K​k′ as KKK-algebras is the same as their tensor product as KKK-vector spaces. In particular, it is non-zero, so we found our SSS!
Here's the proof summarized in a quiver commutative diagram.
@John Baez, for the general question, I'll see what the Stacks Project has to say! (It's probably going to take me a while...).

I guess the lesson I learned here is that "every span in the category of fields may be closed", in the sense that two extensions k,k′′k,k''k,k′′ of a field KKK always have a common extension K0K_0K0​. There's nothing canonical about K0K_0K0​ because it depends on a choice of a maximal ideal of the algebra k⊗Kk′k\otimes_K k'k⊗K​k′, but it exists. This is the "union" Mike was hinting at. The comments in this Math Stack Exchange question seem to say that it is related to the notion of compositum of fields mentioned by John.

The tl;dr version of the proof then is: since ker⁡f=ker⁡f′=:p\ker f=\ker f'=:\mathfrak pkerf=kerf′=:p, both f:R→kf:R\to kf:R→k and f′:R→k′f':R\to k'f′:R→k′ factor through a common field, namely the field of fractions of R/pR/\mathfrak pR/p. Then we conclude by applying the above observation.
